:For the province of Sri Lanka, see [[Northern Province, Sri Lanka|Northern
Province]] (Uturu Palata).

'Uturu' is a rural town located in the south-eastern part of Nigeria, in the
northern part of the state of Abia State, Nigeria. Its popularly known as a
location for several educational institutions and the Marist Brothers community.
Schools in Uturu include Abia State University, Marist Brothers' Juniorate,
Uturu, [http://www.gregoryuniversity.com/ Gregory University Uturu], and several
post-secondary schools.

The population of Uturu has been growing at a high rate over the decades, until
the last decade. Its present population is over 40,000. It has archaeological
importance -in 1977 a team of archaeologists discovered signs of the habitation
of early, middle, and late Stone Age Homo erectus. Chigbu, U.E (2013).
Fostering rural sense of place: the missing piece in Uturu, Nigeria Fostering
rural sense of place: the missing piece in Uturu, Nigeria. Development In
Practice, Vol. 23 (2): pages 264-277. available at
http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/09614524.2013.772120

Uturu is divided into two regions, Ihite and Ikeagha. Ihite comprises Achara and
Mba Ugwu (Ugwu-Ogu, Ugwu-Ele, Ngodo, Amegu, Obi-Agu, Nnembi and Aro). Ikeagha
comprises Isunabo, Akpukpa, Umumara, Nvurunvu, and Ndundu. In Uturu is the
archeological site of Ugwuele, in which was found a huge collection of stone-age
implements, suggesting that the site was a major factory for such tools. {{cite book|postscript= Uturu is believed to have married Nnebo
and they had seven children; six sons and one daughter. The sons are: Achara,
Akpukpa, Isunabo, Umumara, Nvurunvu, and Ndundu. And their daughters name was
Nne Mbu now known as Nnembi. Nne Mbu went on to have these children: Ugwu-Ogu,
Ugwu-Ele, Ngodo, Amegu, Obi-Agu and Aro; they are known as Mba Ugwu.|url=http:/-
